awd_titl_txt: Gravitational Wave Data Analysis: Inferring the Properties of Compact Objects and Searching for New Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is devoted to the analysis and modeling of gravitational waves. These ripples in the very fabric of space and time are produced when the densest objects in the Universe -- such as black holes and neutron stars -- orbit and collide. The detection of gravitational waves by the NSF-funded LIGO and European Virgo collaborations has opened up a new window on the Universe, revealing previously invisible events like pairs of black holes merging. Researchers supported by this award will participate in the analysis of gravitational waves as members of the LIGO collaboration, helping to infer the properties of the sources of these ripples. In addition to these collaboration activities, which have far-reaching impacts on astrophysics, cosmology, and nuclear physics, the research group will carry out searches for new physics using gravitational-wave data. Detections of gravitational waves provide information about spacetime at its most dynamic, allowing for strong-field tests of relativity, as the possibility of detecting extremely compact objects which are otherwise invisible to electromagnetic observations. This award will enable both searches for gravitational waves from new, hypothetical compact stars, and use the final "ringdown" of merged black holes to search for new physics. These research activities will provide training for graduate students in modeling and data analysis, skillsets which are in great demand and of great benefit to society. In addition, members of the group will engage in outreach activities in order to educate and inspire the public about this new field of physics and astronomy.

In particular, this project focuses on searching for new physics with gravitational wave detections, while continuing to support the LIGO Scientific Collaboration by performing Bayesian parameter estimation on detections made in the collaboration's next observing campaign. The PI and other members of the group will participate in the planning and development of parameter estimation pipelines, and carry out  inferences on detections made in low latency. These inferences are a crucial first step in the use of gravitational waves for understanding the populations of compact objects, inferring the nuclear equation of state from observations of binary neutron stars, testing the theory of relativity, and using gravitational waves to measure cosmic expansion. The project will also include the development of accurate, reduced-dimensional waveform models to enable the search for low-mass compact objects with large spin-induced quadrupole moments. Such hypothetical objects can be missed by current searches, and their detection would reveal exotic new physics. The GstLAL search pipeline and random template banks will be used to carry out searches for these systems in publicly available data. The team will also use methods borrowed from quantum mechanical perturbation theory to predict how possible deviations from relativity are imprinted on the ringdown spectrum of spinning black holes. After predicting the changes to the spectrum from particular deviations, Bayesian parameter estimation will be used to constrain or measure the underlying parameters of these models using ringdown signals from previously detected binary black hole mergers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported contributions to the LIGO Scientific Collaboration as well as independent research by the PI?s group. Under this award, our group participated in the transformative research carried out by the LIGO Scientific Collaboration during the award period. LIGO and its partner collaborations use kilometer-scale laser interferometers to detect gravitational waves. These ghostly ripples in the fabric of space and time are produced strongly by the orbits and collisions of ultra-dense objects like neutron stars and black holes.

Our group assisted in the development of our search and data analysis methods leading up to the fourth observational campaign of these extraordinary instruments. As the sensitivity of the LIGO detectors increases, so too does the scale and complexity of our gravitational wave searches and data analysis. Our group participated in the planning for this next campaign and reviewed our existing tools to ensure their readiness. We also participated in the low-latency analysis of signals publicly announced during the engineering and commissioning run leading up to the start of the campaign. We anticipate that this next observational campaign will detect more than a hundred new gravitational wave signals from black holes and neutron stars. This wealth of new data will help us unravel mysteries such as the composition of neutron stars and provide a new probe of our cosmic history.

Our group also investigated the modeling of gravitational wave signals, by comparing the results of numerical simulations of orbiting black holes to ?pen-and-paper? approximations. We focused on an approximation method that assumes the black holes have very different masses, using the formalism of self-force. Our results contribute to a growing body of evidence which shows that this approach remains applicable to systems with nearly equal masses. This is the case for most systems detected by current gravitational wave observatories like the twin LIGO detectors.

We also developed new methods for using gravitational wave data to search for the unexpected. By focusing on the final, rapidly decaying portion of gravitational wave signals, we have begun to develop clean and targeted tests of the theory of relativity, as well as methods to leverage a large number of detections to make these tests as stringent as possible. We also developed entirely new searches for gravitational waves from unexpected sources, namely hypothetical objects which would be almost as dense as neutron stars but include new forms of matter. Systems including such exotic objects can be missed entirely by existing searches, especially when the resulting signals are several seconds long. We carried out the first such search as a proof of principle, and to open new directions in gravitational wave science.

This award also supported activities that broadly benefitted society, through student training and public outreach and education. This award supported research going into a PhD thesis, and helped to train a number of additional students. We helped organize series of public outreach events in the Austin area. The PI also participated in the American Physical Society Bridge Program at UT Austin and gave a week long summer lecture series in support of our program.

In summary, the activities supported by this award enhanced our understanding of some of the most extreme and mysterious objects in our Universe: black holes and neutron stars. Gravitational waves provide a unique window onto these systems, which may be otherwise invisible, but which strongly warp the very fabric of space and time. Continued investigation of these objects through the gravitational waves they emit provides a deeper understanding of the nature of gravity and the cosmos we live in.
